review.title: Particle swarm optimization for time series motif discovery
review.abstract: Efficiently finding similar segments or motifs in time series data is a fundamental task that, due to the ubiquity of these data, is present in a wide range of domains and situations. Because of this, countless solutions have been devised but, to date, none of them seems to be fully satisfactory and flexible. In this article, we propose an innovative standpoint and present a solution coming from it: an anytime multimodal optimization algorithm for time series motif discovery based on particle swarms. By considering data from a variety of domains, we show that this solution is extremely competitive when compared to the state-of-the-art, obtaining comparable motifs in considerably less time using minimal memory. In addition, we show that it is robust to different implementation choices and see that it offers an unprecedented degree of flexibility with regard to the task. All these qualities make the presented solution stand out as one of the most prominent candidates for motif discovery in long time series streams. Besides, we believe the proposed standpoint can be exploited in further time series analysis and mining tasks, widening the scope of research and potentially yielding novel effective solutions.

sections.heading: II. TIME SERIES MOTIF DISCOVERY AS AN ANYTIME MULTIMODAL OPTIMIZATION TASK

sections.heading: A. Definitions and Task Complexity
sections.text: From the work of Mueen et al. [3], [17], we can deduce a formal, generic similarity-based definition [2] of time series motifs. Given a time series z of length n, z = [z1,.. zn], a normalized segment dissimilarity measure D, and a temporal window of interest between wmin and wmax samples, the Topk time series motifs M = {m1,.. mk} correspond to most similar segment pairs zwaa = [za,. za + wa − 1] and z wb = [zb,]. zb + wb − 1], for wa, wb −.a, a, n − wa + 1], and b [1], where we [1, n − wb + 1], where we avoid repeated and trivial matches.

sections.heading: B. Continuity
sections.text: A fundamental property of the time series is autocorrelation, which implies that successive samples in a time series exhibit some degree of similarity and that we do not observe extreme differences between them most of the time.3 This property, together with the established methods of computer similarity between time series [23], is what gives continuity to our search space. Consider a typical dissimilarity measurement such as the dynamic deformation of time between z-normalized segments and the time series of Fig. 1. If we set the starting points of motif a and b to some random values, we can set D (zia, z j b) for i, j = wmin,.

sections.heading: C. Anytime Solutions
sections.text: In fact, most of us are able to play by the rules we have set ourselves in order to fulfil them.

sections.heading: D. Particle Swarm Optimization
sections.text: The continuity and readily available observations above (Sections II-B and II-C) loosen the requirements for the optimization algorithm used in the motif spaces under consideration. In fact, if we do not have to evaluate the global optimality of a solution, we have a number of approaches that can handle large, multimodal, continuous, but noisy search spaces [25] - [27]. Among them, we opt for PSO [30] - [34]. PSO is a population-based stochastic approach to solving continuous and discrete optimization problems [33] that has been applied to multimodal problems [35]. It is metaheurism [27], which means that it cannot guarantee whether the solution found corresponds to a global optimum. The original PSO algorithm cannot even guarantee convergence to a local optimum, but adapted versions of it have been proven to solve this problem [36].

sections.heading: C. Final Performance
sections.text: After expanding SWARMMOTIF with speed limitations and craziness, we evaluate its performance on all time series under consideration using the standard combination of parameters resulting from the previous two sections. As can be seen, the obtained motif differences are in all cases far from the random sample (Fig. 9; note the logarithmic axes). Furthermore, we see that SWARMMOTIF is already able to achieve inconsistencies with inM as soon as its execution begins. Specifically, motif differences in M begin to overlap with those in t < 10 s for virtually all time series. The only exceptions are EOG and RANDOMWALK, where M begins to overlap with t < 100 s. We assume that a smaller number of particles overlap with M may overlap.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this article, we propose an innovative approach to the task of time series discovery by formulating it as a multimodal optimization problem at all times. After a precise but comprehensive literature review, we will establish the new formulation and develop an approach based on the calculation of time series. We will then highlight the various advantages of this new formulation, many of which relate to a high degree of flexibility in the resulting solutions. To get the most out of our knowledge, such a degree of flexibility is invisible in previous work on time series motives. We will present next SWARMOTIF, an always multimodal optimization algorithm for time series motives based on the discovery of particle swarms. We will show that SWARMOTIF is extremely competitive when the best approach we can find in literature.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
sections.text: We would like to thank all those who contributed the data sets used in this study, and Abdullah Mueen for the additional transmission of his code. We would also like to thank Xavier Anguera for the useful discussions that motivated this work, which was funded by the Generalitat de Catalunya 2009-SGR-1434, JAEDOC069 / 2010 by the Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Cienti ́ ficas (JS), TIN2012-38450C03-03 and the funds of the European Union for Social Affairs and Federal Affairs (JS).

The dissimilarity function D can expressly handle segments of different lengths or we can simply upsample to the largest length (see [22]).
Thus, just by replacing D, we are able to work with multi-dimensional time series [37], detect sub-dimensional motifs [38], perform a constrained motif discovery task [16], etc.
Thus, just by replacing D, we are able to work with multi-dimensional time series [37], detect sub-dimensional motifs [38], perform a constrained motif discovery task [16], etc.

The agentbased nature of PSO naturally yields to parallel implementations [32].

Our PSO approach to time series motif discovery is based on the combination of two well-known extensions to the canonical PSO [31].
On one hand, we employ multiple reinitializations of the swarm on stagnation [39].
On the other hand, we exploit the particles’ “local memories” with the intention of forming stable niches across different local minima [40].
The former emulates a parallel multi-swarm approach [35] without the need of having to define the number of swarms and their communication.
The latter, when combined with the former, results in a low-complexity niching strategy [35] that does not require niching parameters (see the related discussion in [41], [42]).

Note that by considering the particles’ neighborhood personal bests pg we follow the aforementioned local neighborhood niching strategy [40].

• Sociability: We study whether a “cognitive-only” model, a “social-only” one, or different weightings of the two yield to some improvements [44].
To do so, we just need to introduce a parameter α ∈ [0, 1] controlling the degree of ‘sociability’ of the particles, and implement lines 1–2 of Algorithm 3 instead of Eq.
• Stochastic: We investigate the use of a random inertia weight [39].
• Velocity clamping: In addition to constriction, we study limiting the maximum velocity of the particles [45].
constriction factor and velocity clamping results in improved performance on certain problems [46].
• Craziness: We introduce so-called “craziness” or “perturbation” in the particles’ velocities, as initially suggested by Kennedy & Eberhart [45].

In such variant, inspired by the sudden direction changes observed in flocking birds, the particles’ velocity is altered with a certain probability ρ, with the aim of favoring exploration by increasing directional diversity and discouraging premature convergence [47].
We coincide with [47] in that, in some sense, this can be seen as a mutation operation.
As a baseline, we use the top25 motifs found by MOEN [3], which we will denote byM∗.

Four of the time series have been used for motif discovery in previous studies [17], [48], while the other five are employed here for the first time for this task:
Four of the time series have been used for motif discovery in previous studies [17], [48], while the other five are employed here for the first time for this task:
1) DOWJONES: The daily closing values of the Dow Jones average in the USA from May 2, 1885 to April 22, 2014 [49].
2) CARCOUNT: The number of cars measured for the Glendale on ramp for the 101 North freeway in Los Angeles, CA, USA [50].
The measurement was carried out by the Freeway Performance Measurement System7 and the data was retrieved from the UCI Machine Learning Repository [51].
3) INSECT: The electrical penetration graph of a beet leafhopper (circulifer tenellus) [17].

5) FIELDRECORDING: The spectral centroid (in Hz) of a field recording retrieved from Freesound10 [52].

8) EOG: An electrooculogram tracking the eye movements of a sleeping patient [54].
We took the downsampled time series [48] from Mueen’s web page13.

First, we consider all settings at the same time and perform the Friedman’s test [55], which is a non-parametric statistical test used to detect differences in treatments across multiple test attempts.
In it, we perform all possible pairwise comparisons between settings using the Wilcoxon signed-rank test [55], another non-parametric statistical hypothesis test used for comparing matched samples.
To counteract the problem of multiple comparisons and control the so-called family-wise error rate, we employ the HolmBonferroni correction [56].
We then experimented with 6 different static topologies θ [57]: global best, local best (two neighbors), Von Neumann, random (three neighbors), wheel, and binary tree.
It is well-known that higher φ values favor exploitation rather than exploration [43].

With regard to the latter, we envision powerful approaches to variable-length local similarity calculations, in the vein of existing dynamic programming approaches [58], [59].

metadata.abstractText: Efficiently finding similar segments or motifs in time series data is a fundamental task that, due to the ubiquity of these data, is present in a wide range of domains and situations. Because of this, countless solutions have been devised but, to date, none of them seems to be fully satisfactory and flexible. In this article, we propose an innovative standpoint and present a solution coming from it: an anytime multimodal optimization algorithm for time series motif discovery based on particle swarms. By considering data from a variety of domains, we show that this solution is extremely competitive when compared to the state-of-the-art, obtaining comparable motifs in considerably less time using minimal memory. In addition, we show that it is robust to different implementation choices and see that it offers an unprecedented degree of flexibility with regard to the task. All these qualities make the presented solution stand out as one of the most prominent candidates for motif discovery in long time series streams. Besides, we believe the proposed standpoint can be exploited in further time series analysis and mining tasks, widening the scope of research and potentially yielding novel effective solutions.
